newsitem.title: USA: U.S. database companies set privacy rules.
newsitem.headline: U.S. database companies set privacy rules.

text.p: Eight information companies including Lexis-Nexis said on Monday they were adopting self-regulatory practices to protect personal information on databases.
The eight companies agreed not to display private information such as an individual's social security number if the information is made available for wide distribution to database clients.
But, a company may make all private information available to certain subscribers, such as law enforcement officers for investigative purposes, the companies said in a statement.
Further details of the rules would be made public on Tuesday at a workshop on consumer information privacy at the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the statement said.
The initiative followed a recent uproar over a service by database company Lexis-Nexis, a division of Reed Elsevier, which sold personal information to lawyers trying to locate parties to a lawsuit.
The uproar was such that in October 1996 three senators called on FTC Chairman Robert Pitofsky to investigate whether databases violate individual privacy.

The database initiative came the same day as a separate proposal by computer makers, software developers, telecommunications firms, retailers and publishers to preserve consumer privacy on the Internet.

The companies involved in the database initiative included CDB Infotek, a division of ChoicePoint; Database Technology Inc ; Experian; First Data InfoSource/Donnelley Marketing; Information America; IRSC Inc; and Metromail Corp.
